creator.name: Rooms-Katholieke kerk
creator.his_func:
The position of the Roman Catholic Church varied in the different areas of the Netherlands West Indies.

 

Curaçao, Aruba, Bonaire

In the 17th and 18th century most Spanish-speaking priests visited the Catholics of Curaçao. Outside Willemstad there were no churches. Between 1776 and 1824 some Dutch Franciscan priests did missionary work on the island. There was no question of a permanent mission.

In 1824 the Franciscans were succeeded by secular clergy from the Netherlands. Until his death in 1860 the Amsterdam priest M.J. Niewindt led the mission; in 1843 he was ordained bishop. New parishes were established, such as Santa Rosa (1837) and Willibrordo (1849). The Franciscan Sisters of Roosendaal (North Brabant) cooperated for educational purposes; after July 1863 they also taught emancipated slave children.

In 1870 the Dutch Dominicans (OP) decided to undertake the pastoral care in the Antilles. They also organized their activities from the different parish churches.

 

Demerara

From 1769 to 1782 two foreign missionaries, an English and a North American, worked in Demerara.

 

Suriname

From 1683 to 1686 there were three Franciscan priests for the spiritual care of Catholic planters in Suriname. A century later, from 1786 to 1865, and on an occasional basis, Dutch secular clergy came to Suriname, for example the priest P. Donders. Only when the end of slavery was apparent did the planters' aversion against the conversion of their slaves to Christianity diminish. Furthermore, after 1856 slave owners were under a legal requirement to allow missionary activity. In 1856 the first congregation arrived: Franciscan Sisters of Roosendaal. They focused on education. In 1865 the mission in Suriname was entrusted to the Netherlands Redemptorist Province (CssR). At the end of March 1866 the first Redemptorists arrived in Paramaribo. They brought continuity and structure to the missionary work, and travelled deeper inland.

 

The Netherlands

The Reformation and the Revolt affected the position of the Roman Catholic Church and its administration in the Northern Netherlands.

The Northern Netherlands, called "Hollandse Zending", was a mission territory directly under the governance of the Roman Board "De Propaganda Fide". An archpriest was a lower ecclesiastical administrator. In 1853 the episcopal hierarchy was restored in the Netherlands.
